CRFL: Certifiably Robust Federated Learning against Backdoor Attacks

Chulin Xie â€ƒâ€ƒ Minghao Chen â€ƒâ€ƒ Pin-Yu Chen â€ƒâ€ƒ Bo Li
Abstract

Federated Learning (FL) as a distributed learning paradigm that aggregates information from diverse clients to train a shared global model, has demonstrated great success. However, malicious clients can perform poisoning attacks and model replacement to introduce backdoors into the trained global model. Although there have been intensive studies designing robust aggregation methods and empirical robust federated training protocols against backdoors, existing approaches lack robustness certification. This paper provides the first general framework, Certifiably Robust Federated Learning (CRFL), to train certifiably robust FL models against backdoors. Our method exploits clipping and smoothing on model parameters to control the global model smoothness, which yields a sample-wise robustness certification on backdoors with limited magnitude. Our certification also specifies the relation to federated learning parameters, such as poisoning ratio on instance level, number of attackers, and training iterations. Practically, we conduct comprehensive experiments across a range of federated datasets, and provide the ï¬rst benchmark for certiï¬ed robustness against backdoor attacks in federated learning. Our code is publicaly available at https://github.com/AI-secure/CRFL.

Machine Learning, ICML

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) has been widely applied to different applications given its high efficiency and privacy-preserving propertiesÂ (Smith etÂ al., 2017; McMahan etÂ al., 2017a; Zhao etÂ al., 2018). However, recent studies show that it is easy for the local client to add adversarial perturbation such as â€œbackdoorsâ€ during training to compromise the final aggregated modelÂ (Bhagoji etÂ al., 2019; Bagdasaryan etÂ al., 2020; Wang etÂ al., 2020; Xie etÂ al., 2019). Such attacks raise great security concerns and have become the roadblocks towards the real-world deployment of federated learning.

Although there have been intensive studies on robust FL by designing robust aggregation methodsÂ (Fung etÂ al., 2020; Pillutla etÂ al., 2019; Fu etÂ al., 2019; Blanchard etÂ al., 2017; ElÂ Mhamdi etÂ al., 2018; Chen etÂ al., 2017; Yin etÂ al., 2018), developing empirically robust federated training protocols (e.g., gradient clippingÂ (Sun etÂ al., 2019), leveraging noisy perturbationÂ (Sun etÂ al., 2019) and additional evaluation during trainingÂ (Andreina etÂ al., 2020)), current defense approaches lack robustness guarantees against the backdoor attacks under certain conditions. To the best of our knowledge, certified robustness analysis and algorithms for FL against backdoor attacks remain elusive.

To bridge this gap, in this work we propose a certifiably robust federated learning (CRFL) framework as illustrated in FigureÂ 1. In particular, during training, we allow the local agent to update their model parameters to the center server, and the server will: 1) aggregate the collected model updates, 2) clip the norm of the aggregated model parameters, 3) add a random noise to the clipped model, and finally 4) send the new model parameters back to each agent. Note that all of the operations are conducted on the server side to reduce the load for local clients and to prevent malicious clients. During testing, the server will smooth the final global model with randomized parameter smoothing and make the final prediction based on the parameter-smoothed model.

Using CRFL, we theoretically prove that the trained global model would be certifiably robust against backdoors as long as the backdoor is within our certified bound. To obtain such robustness certification, we first quantify the closeness of models aggregated in each step by viewing this process as a Markov KernelÂ (Asoodeh & Calmon, 2020; Makur, 2019; Polyanskiy & Wu, 2015, 2017). We then leverage the model closeness together with the parameter smoothing procedure to certify the final prediction. Empirically, we conduct extensive evaluations on MNIST, EMNIST, and financial datasets to evaluate the certified robustness of CRFL and study how FL parameters affect certified robustness.

Technical Contributions. In this paper, we take the first step towards providing certified robustness for FL against backdoor attacks. We make contributions on both theoretical and empirical fronts.

  • â€¢

    We propose the first certifiably robust federated learning (CRFL) framework against backdoor attacks.

  • â€¢

    Theoretically, we analyze the training dynamics of the aggregated model via Markov Kernel, and propose parameter smoothing for model inference. Altogether, we prove the certified robustness of CRFL.

  • â€¢

    We conduct extensive experiments on MNIST, EMNIST, and financial datasets to show the effect of different FL parameters (e.g. poisoning ratio, number of attackers, and training iterations) on certified robustness.

2 Related work

Backdoor Attacks on Federated Learning

The goal of backdoor attacks against federated learning is to train strong poisoned local models and submit malicious model updates to the central server, so as to mislead the global modelÂ (Bhagoji etÂ al., 2019). (Bagdasaryan etÂ al., 2020) studies the model replacement approach, where the attacker scales malicious model updates to replace the global model with local backdoored one. (Xie etÂ al., 2019) exploit the decentralized nature of federated learning and propose a distributed backdoor attack.

Robust Federated Learning

In order to nullify the effects of attacks while aggregating client updates, a number of robust aggregation algorithms have been proposed for distributed learningÂ (Fung etÂ al., 2020; Pillutla etÂ al., 2019; Fu etÂ al., 2019; Blanchard etÂ al., 2017; ElÂ Mhamdi etÂ al., 2018; Chen etÂ al., 2017; Yin etÂ al., 2018). These methods either identify and down-weight the malicious updates through certain distance or similarity metrics, or estimate a true â€œcenterâ€ of the received model updates rather than taking a weighted average. However, many of those methods assume that the data distribution is i.i.d cross distributed clients, which is not the case in FL setting. Other defenses are several robust federated protocols that mitigate poisoning attacks during training. (Andreina etÂ al., 2020) incorporates an additional validation phase to each round of FL to detect backdoor. (Sun etÂ al., 2019) show that clipping the norm of model updates and adding Gaussian noise can mitigate backdoor attacks that are based on the model replacement paradigm. None of these provides certified robustness guarantees.

A concurrent workÂ (Cao etÂ al., 2021) proposes Ensemble FL for provable secure FL against malicious clients, which requires training hundreds of FL models and focuses on client-level certification. Our work allows standard FL protocol, and our certification is applicable to feature, sample, and client levels.

3.2 Threat Model

The goal of backdoor is to inject a backdoor pattern during training such that any test input with such pattern will be mis-classified as the target labelÂ (Gu etÂ al., 2019). The purpose of backdoor attacks in FL is to manipulate local models and simultaneously fit the main task and backdoor task, so that the global model would behave normally on untampered data samples while achieving high attack success rate on backdoored data samples. We consider the backdoor attack via model replacement approachÂ (Bagdasaryan etÂ al., 2020) where the attackers train the local models using the poisoned datasets, and scale the malicious updates before sending it to the sever. Suppose there are Rğ‘…R adversarial clients out of Nğ‘N clients, we assume that each of them only attack once and they perform model replacement attack together at the same round ğ—ğ–ºğ–½ğ—subscriptğ—ğ–ºğ–½ğ—\mathsf{t_{adv}}. Such distributed yet coordinated backdoor attack is shown to be effective inÂ (Xie etÂ al., 2019).

4 Methodology

In this Section, we introduce our proposed framework CRFL, which is composed of a training-time subroutine (AlgorithmÂ 1) and a test-time subroutine (AlgorithmÂ 2) for achieving certified robustness.

4.2 CRFL Testing: Parameter Smoothing

Smoothed Classifiers

We study multi-class classification models and define a classifier h:(ğ’²,ğ’³)â†’ğ’´:â„â†’ğ’²ğ’³ğ’´h:\mathcal{(W,X)}\rightarrow\mathcal{Y} with finite set of label ğ’´={1,â€¦,C}ğ’´1â€¦ğ¶\mathcal{Y}=\{1,\ldots,C\}, where Cğ¶C denotes the number of classes. We leave the function CalculateRadiusCalculateRadius\mathrm{CalculateRadius} to be defined with our main results in later sections and we will analyze the robustness properties of the model trained and tested under our framework CRFL.

Comparison with Certifiably Robust Models in Centralized Setting

Our method is different from previous certifiably robust models in centralized learning against evasion attacksÂ (Cohen etÂ al., 2019) and backdoorsÂ (Weber etÂ al., 2020). Once the Mğ‘€M noisy models (at round Tğ‘‡T, with ÏƒTsubscriptğœğ‘‡\sigma_{T}) are generated, they are fixed and used for every test sample during test time, just like RAB (Weber etÂ al., 2020) in the centralized setting. However, RAB actually trains Mğ‘€M models using Mğ‘€M noise-corrupted datasets, while we just train one model through FL and finally generated Mğ‘€M noise-corrupted copies of it. For every test sample, randomized smoothing (Cohen etÂ al., 2019) generates Mğ‘€M noisy samples. Suppose the test set size is mğ‘šm. Then during testing, there are mâ‹…Mâ‹…ğ‘šğ‘€m\cdot M times noise addition on test samples for randomized smoothing, and Mğ‘€M times noises addition on trained model for CRFL. To our best knowledge, this is the first work to study parameter smoothing rather than input smoothing, which is an open problem motivated by the FL scenario, since the sever directly aggregates over the model parameters.

5 Certified Robustness of CRFL

5.1 Pointwise Certified Robustness

Goal of Certification

In the context of data poisoning in federated learning, the goal is to protect the global model against adversarial data modification made to the local training sets of distributed clients. Thus, the goal of certifiable robustness in federated learning is for each test point, to return a prediction as well as a certificate that the prediction would not change had some features in (part of) local training data of certain clients been modified.

Following our threat model in SectionÂ 3.2 and our training protocol in AlgorithmÂ 1, we define the trained global model â„³â€‹(Dâ€²):=ClipÏTâ€‹(wâ€²T).assignâ„³superscriptğ·â€²subscriptClipsubscriptğœŒğ‘‡subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤â€²ğ‘‡\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime}):=\mathrm{Clip}_{\rho_{T}}({w^{\prime}}_{T}). For the FL training process that is exposed to model replacement attack, when the distance between Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime} (backdoored dataset) and Dğ·D (clean dataset) is under certain threshold (i.e., the magnitude of {{Î´i}j=1qi}i=1Rsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘–ğ‘—1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘…\{\{\delta_{i}\}_{j=1}^{q_{i}}\}_{i=1}^{R} is bounded), we can certify that â„³â€‹(Dâ€²)â„³superscriptğ·â€²\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime}) is â€œcloseâ€ to â„³â€‹(D)â„³ğ·\mathcal{M}(D) and thus is robust to backdoors. The rationale lies in the fact that we perform clipping and noise perturbation on the model parameters to control the global model deviation during training. During testing, intuitively, under the Gaussian smoothing measures Î¼ğœ‡\mu as described in AlgorithmÂ 2, for two close distribution Î¼â€‹(â„³â€‹(Dâ€²))ğœ‡â„³superscriptğ·â€²\mu(\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime})) and Î¼â€‹(â„³â€‹(D))ğœ‡â„³ğ·\mu(\mathcal{M}(D)), we would expect that even though the probabilities for each class cğ‘c, i.e., Hscâ€‹(â„³â€‹(Dâ€²);xtâ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹t)superscriptsubscriptğ»ğ‘ ğ‘â„³superscriptğ·â€²subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡{H_{s}^{c}}(\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime});x_{test}) and Hscâ€‹(â„³â€‹(D);xtâ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹t)superscriptsubscriptğ»ğ‘ ğ‘â„³ğ·subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡{H_{s}^{c}}(\mathcal{M}(D);x_{test}), may not be equal, the returned most likely label hsâ€‹(â„³â€‹(Dâ€²);xtâ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹t)subscriptâ„ğ‘ â„³superscriptğ·â€²subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡{h_{s}}(\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime});x_{test}) and hsâ€‹(â„³â€‹(D);xtâ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹t)subscriptâ„ğ‘ â„³ğ·subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡{h_{s}}(\mathcal{M}(D);x_{test}) should be consistent.

In summary, we aim to develop a robustness certificate by studying under what condition for {{Î´i}j=1qi}i=1Rsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘–ğ‘—1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘…\{\{\delta_{i}\}_{j=1}^{q_{i}}\}_{i=1}^{R} that the prediction for a test sample is consistent between the smoothed FL models trained from Dğ·D and Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime} separately, i.e., hsâ€‹(â„³â€‹(Dâ€²);xtâ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹t)=hsâ€‹(â„³â€‹(D);xtâ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹t)subscriptâ„ğ‘ â„³superscriptğ·â€²subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptâ„ğ‘ â„³ğ·subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡{h_{s}}(\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime});x_{test})={h_{s}}(\mathcal{M}(D);x_{test}). To put forth our certified robustness analysis, we make the following assumptions on the loss function of all clients. Then we present our main theorem and explain its derivation through model closeness and parameter smoothing. The assumptions on convexity and smoothness are common in the analysis of distributed SGD (Li etÂ al., 2020; Wang & Joshi, 2019). We now make several remarks about CorollaryÂ 1 and will verify them in our experiments: 1) The noise level Ïƒtsubscriptğœğ‘¡\sigma_{t} and the parameter norm clipping threshold ÏtsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡\rho_{t} are hyper-parameters that can be adjusted to control the robustness-accuracy trade-off. For instance, the certified radius ğ–±ğ– ğ–£ğ–±ğ– ğ–£\mathsf{RAD} would be large when: Ïƒtsubscriptğœğ‘¡\sigma_{t} is high; ÏtsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡\rho_{t} is small; the margin between pAÂ¯Â¯subscriptğ‘ğ´\underline{p_{A}} and pBÂ¯Â¯subscriptğ‘ğµ\overline{p_{B}} is large; the number of attackers Rğ‘…R is small; the poison ratio qBinBisubscriptsubscriptğ‘ğµğ‘–subscriptsubscriptğ‘›ğµğ‘–\frac{{{q_{B}}_{i}}}{{{n_{B}}_{i}}} is small; the scale factor Î³isubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\gamma_{i} is small; the aggregation weights for attackers pisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–p_{i} is small; the local iteration Ï„isubscriptğœğ‘–\tau_{i} is small; and the local learning rate Î·isubscriptğœ‚ğ‘–\eta_{i} small. 2) Since 0â‰¤2â€‹Î¦â€‹(â‹…)âˆ’1â‰¤102Î¦â‹…110\leq 2\Phi(\cdot)-1\leq 1, the certified radius ğ–±ğ– ğ–£ğ–±ğ– ğ–£\mathsf{RAD} goes to âˆ\infty as Tâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘‡T\rightarrow\infty when Î¦â€‹(â‹…)<1Î¦â‹…1\Phi(\cdot)<1. Ituitively, the benign fine-tuning after backdoor injection round ğ—ğ–ºğ–½ğ—subscriptğ—ğ–ºğ–½ğ—\mathsf{t_{adv}} would mitegate the poisoning effect. Thus, with infinite rounds of such fine-tuning, the model is able to tolerate backdoors with arbitrarily large magnitude. In practice, we note that the continued multiplication in the denominator may not approach 0 due to numerical issues, which we will verify in the experiments section. 4) Large number of clients Nğ‘N will decrease the aggregation weights pisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–p_{i} of attackers, thus it can tolerate backdoors with large magnitude, resulting in higher ğ–±ğ– ğ–£ğ–±ğ– ğ–£\mathsf{RAD}. 5) For general neural networks, efficient computation of Lipschitz gradient constant (w.r.t. data input) is an open question, especially when the data dimension is high. We will provide a closed-form expression for Lğ’µsubscriptğ¿ğ’µL_{\mathcal{Z}} under some constraints next.

As mentioned in SectionÂ 3.2, the backdoor for data sample zjisuperscriptsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘—ğ‘–z_{j}^{i} includes both the backdoor pattern Î´ixsubscriptğ›¿subscriptğ‘–ğ‘¥\delta_{i_{x}} and adversarial target label flipping Î´iysubscriptğ›¿subscriptğ‘–ğ‘¦\delta_{i_{y}}. In Assumption 2 we define Lğ’µsubscriptğ¿ğ’µL_{\mathcal{Z}} with z={x,y}ğ‘§ğ‘¥ğ‘¦z=\{x,y\} (concatenation of xğ‘¥x and yğ‘¦y) to certify against both backdoor patterns and label-flipping effects. Without loss of generality, here we focus on backdoor patterns considering bounded model parameters in LemmaÂ 1, which provides a closed-form expression for Lğ’µsubscriptğ¿ğ’µL_{\mathcal{Z}} in the case of multi-class logistic regression. By applying Lğ’µsubscriptğ¿ğ’µL_{\mathcal{Z}} from LemmaÂ 1 to TheoremÂ 1, it indicates that the prediction for a test sample is independent with the backdoor pattern so the backdoor pattern is disentangled from the adversarial target label.

Lemma 1.

Given the upper bound on model parameters norm, i.e., â€–wâ€–â‰¤Ïnormğ‘¤ğœŒ\|w\|\leq\rho, and two data samples z1subscriptğ‘§1z_{1} and z2subscriptğ‘§2z_{2} with x1â‰ x2subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¥2x_{1}\neq x_{2} (y1=y2subscriptğ‘¦1subscriptğ‘¦2y_{1}=y_{2}), for multi-class logistic regression (i.e., one linear layer followed by a softmax function and trained by cross-entropy loss), its Lipschitz gradient constant w.r.t data is Lğ’µ=2+2â€‹Ï+Ï2subscriptğ¿ğ’µ22ğœŒsuperscriptğœŒ2L_{\mathcal{Z}}=\sqrt{2+2\rho+\rho^{2}}. That is,

â€–âˆ‡â„“â€‹(w;z1)âˆ’âˆ‡â„“â€‹(w;z2)â€–â‰¤2+2â€‹Ï+Ï2â€‹â€–z1âˆ’z2â€–.normâˆ‡â„“ğ‘¤subscriptğ‘§1âˆ‡â„“ğ‘¤subscriptğ‘§222ğœŒsuperscriptğœŒ2normsubscriptğ‘§1subscriptğ‘§2\|\nabla\ell(w;z_{1})-\nabla\ell(w;z_{2})\|\leq\sqrt{2+2\rho+\rho^{2}}\|z_{1}-z_{2}\|.

Proof for LemmaÂ 1 is provided in the Appendix B.6.

In order to formally derive the main theorem, there are two key results. We first quantify the closeness between the FL trained models â„³â€‹(Dâ€²)â„³superscriptğ·â€²\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime}) and â„³(D))\mathcal{M}(D)) using Markov Kernel, and then connect the model closeness to the prediction consistency through parameter smoothing.

5.2 Model Closeness

As described in Algorithm 1, owing to the Gaussian noise perturbation mechanism, in each iteration the global model can be viewed as a random vector with the Gaussian smoothing measure Î¼ğœ‡\mu. We use the f-divergence between Î¼â€‹(â„³â€‹(Dâ€²))ğœ‡â„³superscriptğ·â€²\mu(\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime})) and Î¼â€‹(â„³â€‹(D))ğœ‡â„³ğ·\mu(\mathcal{M}(D)) as a statistical distance for measuring model closeness of the final FL model. Based on the data post-processing inequality, when we interpret each round of CRFL as a probability transition kernel, i.e., a Markov Kernel, the contraction coefficient of Markov Kernel can help bound the divergence over multiple training rounds of FL.

Let f:(0,âˆ)â†’â„:ğ‘“â†’0â„f:(0,\infty)\rightarrow\mathbb{R} be a convex function with fâ€‹(1)=0ğ‘“10f(1)=0, Î¼ğœ‡\mu and Î½ğœˆ\nu be two probability distributions. Then the f-divergence is defined as Df(Î¼||Î½)=EWâˆ¼Î½[f(Î¼â€‹(W)Î½â€‹(W))].D_{f}(\mu||\nu)=E_{W\sim\nu}[f(\frac{\mu(W)}{\nu(W)})]. Common choices of f-divergence include total variation (fâ€‹(x)=12â€‹â€–xâˆ’1â€–ğ‘“ğ‘¥12normğ‘¥1f(x)=\frac{1}{2}\|x-1\|) and Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence (fâ€‹(x)=xâ€‹logâ¡xğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ‘¥f(x)=x\log x). The data processing inequality (Raginsky, 2016; Polyanskiy & Wu, 2015, 2017) for the relative entropy states that, for any convex function fğ‘“f and any probability transition kernel (Markov Kernel), Df(Î¼K||Î½K)â‰¤Df(Î¼||Î½)D_{f}(\mu K||\nu K)\leq D_{f}(\mu||\nu), where Î¼â€‹Kğœ‡ğ¾\mu K denotes the push-forward of Î¼ğœ‡\mu by Kğ¾K, i.e., Î¼â€‹K=âˆ«Î¼â€‹(dâ€‹W)â€‹Kâ€‹(W)ğœ‡ğ¾ğœ‡ğ‘‘ğ‘Šğ¾ğ‘Š\mu K=\int\mu(dW)K(W). In other words, Df(Î¼||Î½)D_{f}(\mu||\nu) decreases by post-processing via Kğ¾K. (Asoodeh & Calmon, 2020) extend it to analyze SGD.

In our setting, all the operations in one round of our CRFL, including SGD, clipping and noise perturbations, are incorporated as a Markov Kernel. We note that in the single-round attack setting, the adversarial clients use clean datasets to train the local models after ğ—ğ–ºğ–½ğ—subscriptğ—ğ–ºğ–½ğ—\mathsf{t_{adv}}, so the Markov operator is the same as the one in the benign training process. Therefore the f-divergence of the two global models (backdoored and benign) of interest decreases over rounds, which is characterized by a contraction coefficient defined in Appendix B. We quantify such contraction property of Markov Kernel for each round with the help of two hyperparameters in the server side: model parameter norm clipping threshold ÏtsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡\rho_{t} and the noise level Ïƒtsubscriptğœğ‘¡\sigma_{t}, and finally bound f-divergence of global models in round Tğ‘‡T. Although our analysis can be adopted to general f-divergence, we here use KL divergence as an instantiation to measure the model closeness.

Theorem 2.

When Î·iâ‰¤1Î²subscriptğœ‚ğ‘–1ğ›½\eta_{i}\leq\frac{1}{\beta} and AssumptionsÂ 1,Â 2, andÂ 3 hold, the KL divergence between Î¼â€‹(â„³â€‹(D))ğœ‡â„³ğ·\mu(\mathcal{M}(D)) and Î¼â€‹(â„³â€‹(Dâ€²))ğœ‡â„³superscriptğ·â€²\mu(\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime})) with Î¼â€‹(w)=ğ’©â€‹(w,ÏƒT2â€‹ğˆ)ğœ‡ğ‘¤ğ’©ğ‘¤superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘‡2ğˆ\mu(w)=\mathcal{N}(w,{\sigma_{T}}^{2}\bf I) is bounded as:

The proof is provided in the Appendix B.

5.3 Parameter Smoothing

We connect the model closeness to the prediction consistency by the following theorem. The smoothed classifier hssubscriptâ„ğ‘ h_{s} is robustly certified at Î¼â€‹(wâ€²)ğœ‡superscriptğ‘¤â€²\mu(w^{\prime}) with respect to the bounded KL divergence, DKâ€‹Lâ€‹(Î¼â€‹(w),Î¼â€‹(wâ€²))â‰¤Ïµsubscriptğ·ğ¾ğ¿ğœ‡ğ‘¤ğœ‡superscriptğ‘¤â€²italic-ÏµD_{KL}(\mu(w),\mu(w^{\prime}))\leq\epsilon.

Finally, combining TheoremÂ 2 and Â 3 leads to our main Theorem 1. In detail, TheoremÂ 2 states that DKâ€‹L(Î¼(â„³(D))||Î¼(â„³(Dâ€²)))D_{KL}(\mu(\mathcal{M}(D))||\mu(\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime}))) under our CRFL framework is bounded by certain value that depends on the difference between Dğ·D and Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}. TheoremÂ 3 states that for a test sample xtâ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹tsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡x_{test}, as long as the KL divergence is smaller than âˆ’logâ¡(1âˆ’(pAÂ¯âˆ’pBÂ¯)2)1superscriptÂ¯subscriptğ‘ğ´Â¯subscriptğ‘ğµ2-\log(1-(\sqrt{\underline{p_{A}}}-\sqrt{\overline{p_{B}}})^{2}), the prediction from the poisoned smoothed classifier hssubscriptâ„ğ‘ h_{s} that is built upon the base classifier with model parameter â„³â€‹(Dâ€²)â„³superscriptğ·â€²\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime}) will be consistent with the prediction from hssubscriptâ„ğ‘ h_{s} that is built upon â„³â€‹(D)â„³ğ·\mathcal{M}(D). Therefore, we derive the condition for Dğ·D and Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime} in TheoremÂ 1, under which DKâ€‹L(Î¼(â„³(D))||Î¼(â„³(Dâ€²)))â‰¤âˆ’log(1âˆ’(pAÂ¯âˆ’pBÂ¯)2)D_{KL}(\mu(\mathcal{M}(D))||\mu(\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime})))\leq-\log(1-(\sqrt{\underline{p_{A}}}-\sqrt{\overline{p_{B}}})^{2}). This condition also indicates that hssubscriptâ„ğ‘ h_{s} built upon the model parameter â„³â€‹(Dâ€²)â„³superscriptğ·â€²\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime}) is certifiably robust.

Defend against Other Potential Attack

Here we discuss the potentials to generalize our method against other training-time attacks. 1) Our method can naturally extend to fixed-frequency attack by applying our analysis for each attack period. In particular, we can repeatedly apply our TheoremÂ 2 to analyze model closeness for each attack period, and the different initializations of each period can be bounded based on its last period. Then TheoremÂ 3 can be applied to connect model closeness to certify the prediction consistency. 2) (Wang etÂ al., 2020) introduce edge-case adversarial training samples to enforce the model to misclassify inputs on the tail of input distribution. The edge-case attack essentially conducts a special semantic attackÂ (Bagdasaryan etÂ al., 2020) by selecting rare images instead of directly adding backdoor patterns. It is possible to apply our framework against such attack by viewing it as the whole sample manipulation.

Comparison with Differentially Private Federated Learning

In order to protect the privacy of each client, differentially private federated learning (DPFL) mechanisms are proposedÂ (Geyer etÂ al., 2017; McMahan etÂ al., 2018; Agarwal etÂ al., 2018) to ensure that the learned FL model is essentially unchanged when one individual client is modified. Compared with DPFL, our method has several fundamental differences and addresses additional challenges: 1) Mechanisms: DPFL approaches add training-time noise to provide privacy guarantee, while ours add smoothing noise during training and testing to provide certified robustness against data poisoning. In general, the added noise in CRFL does not need to be as large as that in DPFL to provide strong privacy guarantee, and therefore preserve higher model utility. 2) Certification goals: DPFL approaches provide client-level privacy guarantee for the learned model parameters, while in CRFL the robustness guarantee is derived for certified pointwise prediction which could be on the feature, samples and clients levels. 3) Technical contributions: DPFL approaches derive DP guarantee via DP composition theoremsÂ (Dwork etÂ al., 2014; Abadi etÂ al., 2016), while we quantify the global model deviation via Markov Kernel and verify the robustness properties of the smoothed model via parameter smoothing.

6 Experiments

In our experiments, the attackers perform the model replacement attack at round ğ—ğ–ºğ–½ğ—subscriptğ—ğ–ºğ–½ğ—\mathsf{t_{adv}} during our CRFL training, and the server performs parameter smoothing on a possibly backdoored FL model at round Tğ‘‡T to calculate the certified radius ğ–±ğ– ğ–£ğ–±ğ– ğ–£\mathsf{RAD} for each test sample based on CorollaryÂ 1. Specifically, we evaluate the effect of the training time noise Ïƒtsubscriptğœğ‘¡\sigma_{t}, the attackerâ€™s ability which includes the number of attackers Rğ‘…R, the poison ratio qBinBisubscriptğ‘subscriptğµğ‘–subscriptğ‘›subscriptğµğ‘–\frac{q_{B_{i}}}{n_{B_{i}}} and the scale factor Î³isubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\gamma_{i}, robust aggregation protocol, the number of total clients Nğ‘N and the number of training rounds Tğ‘‡T. Moreover, we evaluate the model closeness empirically to justify Theorem 2.

6.1 Experiment Setup

We focus on multi-class logistic regression (one linear layer with softmax function and cross-entropy loss), which is a convex classification problem. We train the FL system following our CRFL framework with three datasets: Lending Club Loan Data (LOAN)Â (Kan, 2019), MNISTÂ (LeCun & Cortes, 2010), and EMNISTÂ (Cohen etÂ al., 2017). We refer the readers to Appendix A for more details about the datasets, parameter setups and attack setting. We train the FL global model until convergence and then use our certification in AlgorithmÂ 2 for robustness evaluation.

The metrics of interest are certified rate and certified accuracy. Given a test set of size mğ‘šm, for iğ‘–i-th test sample, the ground truth label is yisubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–y_{i}, and the output prediction is either cisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–c_{i} with the certified radius ğ–±ğ– ğ–£isubscriptğ–±ğ– ğ–£ğ‘–\mathsf{RAD}_{i} or ci=ABSTAINsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ABSTAINc_{i}=\texttt{ABSTAIN} with ğ–±ğ– ğ–£i=0subscriptğ–±ğ– ğ–£ğ‘–0\mathsf{RAD}_{i}=0. Then we calculate certified rate at rğ‘Ÿr as 1mâ€‹âˆ‘i=1mğŸ™â€‹{ğ–±ğ– ğ–£iâ‰¥r}1ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘šdouble-struck-ğŸ™subscriptğ–±ğ– ğ–£ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿ\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\mathbb{1}\{\mathsf{RAD}_{i}\geq r\} , and certified accuracy at rğ‘Ÿr as 1mâˆ‘i=1mğŸ™{ci=yi\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\mathbb{1}\{c_{i}=y_{i} and ğ–±ğ– ğ–£iâ‰¥r}\mathsf{RAD}_{i}\geq r\}. The certified rate is the fraction of the test set that can be certified at radius ğ–±ğ– ğ–£â‰¥rğ–±ğ– ğ–£ğ‘Ÿ\mathsf{RAD}\geq r, which reveals how consistent the possibly backdoored classifierâ€™s prediction with the clean classifierâ€™s prediction. The certified accuracy is the fraction of the test set for which the possibly backdoored classifier makes correct and consistent predictions with the clean model. In the displayed figures, there is a critical radius beyond which the certified accuracy and certified rate are dropped to zero. Since each test sample has its own calculated certified radius ğ–±ğ– ğ–£isubscriptğ–±ğ– ğ–£ğ‘–\mathsf{RAD}_{i}, this critical value is a threshold that none of them have a larger radius than it, similar to the findings in (Cohen etÂ al., 2019). We certified 10000/5000/10000 samples from the LOAN/MNIST/EMNIST test sets. In all experiments, unless otherwise stated, we use ÏƒT=0.01subscriptğœğ‘‡0.01\sigma_{T}=0.01 to generate M=1000ğ‘€1000M=1000 noisy models in parameter smoothing procedure, and use the error tolerance Î±=0.001ğ›¼0.001\alpha=0.001. In our experiments, we adopt the expression of Lğ’µsubscriptğ¿ğ’µL_{\mathcal{Z}} in LemmaÂ 1. Lğ’µsubscriptğ¿ğ’µL_{\mathcal{Z}} can be generalized to other poisoning settings by specifying z1,z2subscriptğ‘§1subscriptğ‘§2z_{1},z_{2} in AssumptionÂ 2 under the case of â€œx1â‰ x2subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¥2x_{1}\neq x_{2} and y1â‰ y2subscriptğ‘¦1subscriptğ‘¦2y_{1}\neq y_{2}â€ or â€œx1=x2subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¥2x_{1}=x_{2} and y1â‰ y2subscriptğ‘¦1subscriptğ‘¦2y_{1}\neq y_{2}â€.

6.2 Experiment Results

We only change one factor in each experiment and keep others the same as the experiment setup. We plot the certified accuracy and certified rate on the clean test set, and report the results on the backdoored test set in AppendixÂ A.

Effect of Training Time Noise

Since we aim to defend against backdoor attack, the training time noise Ïƒğœ\sigma (Ïƒ=Ïƒt,t<Tformulae-sequenceğœsubscriptğœğ‘¡ğ‘¡ğ‘‡\sigma=\sigma_{t},t<T) in our AlgorithmÂ 1 is more essential than ÏƒTsubscriptğœğ‘‡\sigma_{T} in parameter smoothing (AlgorithmÂ 2). The reason is that Ïƒğœ\sigma can nullify the malicious model updates at early stage. FigureÂ 2 plots the certified accuracy and certified rate attained by training FL system with different Ïƒğœ\sigma. In FigureÂ 2(a), when Ïƒğœ\sigma is high, certified rate is high at every rğ‘Ÿr and large radius can be certified. FigureÂ 2(b)(c)(d) show that large radius is certified but at a low accuracy, so the parameter noise Ïƒğœ\sigma controls the trade-off between certifiability and accuracy, which echoes the property of evasion-attack certificationÂ (Cohen etÂ al., 2019). Comparing the solid line with the dashed line for each color, we can see that the parameter smoothing with ÏƒTsubscriptğœğ‘‡\sigma_{T} does not hurt the accuracy much.

Effect of Attacker Ability

From the perspective of attackers, the larger number of attackers Rğ‘…R, the larger poison ratio qBinBisubscriptğ‘subscriptğµğ‘–subscriptğ‘›subscriptğµğ‘–\frac{q_{B_{i}}}{n_{B_{i}}} and the larger scale factor Î³isubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\gamma_{i} result in the stronger attack. FigureÂ 3, FigureÂ 4, and FigureÂ 5 show that in the three datasets, the stronger the attack, the smaller radius can be certified. After training sufficient number of rounds with clean datasets after ğ—ğ–ºğ–½ğ—subscriptğ—ğ–ºğ–½ğ—\mathsf{t_{adv}}, we show that the certified radius is not sensitive to the attack timing ğ—ğ–ºğ–½ğ—subscriptğ—ğ–ºğ–½ğ—\mathsf{t_{adv}} in AppendixÂ A.2.

Effect of Robust Aggregation

Our CRFL can be used to assess different robust aggregation rules. FigureÂ 6 presents the certified accuracy on MNIST and EMNIST as Rğ‘…R is varied, when our CRFL adopts the robust aggregation algorithm RFAÂ (Pillutla etÂ al., 2019), which detects outliers and down-weights the malicious updates during aggregation. Comparing FedAvg in FigureÂ 5 with RFA in FigureÂ 6 (the magnitude of x-axis is different), we observe that very large radius can be certified under RFA. This is because that the attacker is assigned with very low aggregation weights pisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–p_{i}, which is part of our bound in Eq.Â 2. Our certified radius reveals that RFA is much robust than FedAvg, which shows the potential usage of our certified radius as an evaluation metric for the robustness of other robust aggregation rules.

Effect of Client Number

Distributed learning across a large number of clients is an important property of FL. FigureÂ 7 shows that large radius can be certified when Nğ‘N is large (i.e., more clients can tolerant larger backdoor magnitude), because it decreases the aggregation weights pisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–p_{i} of attackers. Moreover, the backdoor effect could be mitigated by more benign model updates during training.

Effect of Training Rounds

According to FigureÂ 8, the certified accuracy is higher when Tğ‘‡T is larger. However, the largest radius that can be certified for the test set does not increase. We note that this is due to numerical issues of the standard Gaussian CDF Î¦â€‹(â‹…)Î¦â‹…\Phi(\cdot). As we mentioned in Section 5.1, the continued multiplication in the denominator of Eq.Â 2 will not achieve 0 in practice. Otherwise the certified radius ğ–±ğ– ğ–£ğ–±ğ– ğ–£\mathsf{RAD} goes to âˆ\infty as Tâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘‡T\rightarrow\infty since 0â‰¤2â€‹Î¦â€‹(Ï/Ïƒ)âˆ’1â‰¤102Î¦ğœŒğœ110\leq 2\Phi(\rho/\sigma)-1\leq 1.

To verify our argument, we fix pAÂ¯Â¯subscriptğ‘ğ´\underline{p_{A}} and pBÂ¯Â¯subscriptğ‘ğµ\overline{p_{B}} to be 0.7 and 0.1, use default values for other parameters, and study the relationship between Ï/ÏƒğœŒğœ\rho/\sigma, Tğ‘‡T and ğ–±ğ– ğ–£ğ–±ğ– ğ–£\mathsf{RAD} in FigureÂ 9(b). When Ï/ÏƒğœŒğœ\rho/\sigma is larger than certain threshold, the certified radius ğ–±ğ– ğ–£ğ–±ğ– ğ–£\mathsf{RAD} does not change much when Tğ‘‡T increases. If one wishes to increase Tğ‘‡T for improving certified radius, then we suggest to keep Ï/ÏƒğœŒğœ\rho/\sigma smaller than the threshold to make effect. The increased certified accuracy when Tğ‘‡T is large in FigureÂ 8 could be attributed to improved model performance up to convergence, so the margin between pAÂ¯âˆ’pBÂ¯Â¯subscriptğ‘ğ´Â¯subscriptğ‘ğµ\underline{p_{A}}-\overline{p_{B}} is widened.

We also study the error tolerance Î±ğ›¼\alpha and the number of noisy models Mğ‘€M in Appendix A.2. Larger Mğ‘€M yields larger certified radius, and the certified radius is not very sensitive to Î±ğ›¼\alpha.

Empirical Evaluation on Model Closeness

Our theorems are derived based on the analysis in comparison to a â€œvirtualâ€ benign training process. Empirically, we train such FL global model under the benign training process and compare the â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2} distance between the clean global model and the backdoored global model at every round. In FigureÂ 9(a), one attacker performs model replacement attack on MNIST at round ğ—ğ–ºğ–½ğ—subscriptğ—ğ–ºğ–½ğ—\mathsf{t_{adv}}= {20,40,60}204060\{20,40,60\} respectively. We can observe that the plotted â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2} distance over the FL training rounds after ğ—ğ–ºğ–½ğ—subscriptğ—ğ–ºğ–½ğ—\mathsf{t_{adv}} is decreasing, which echos our assumption that because all clients behave normal and use their clean local datasets to purify the global model after ğ—ğ–ºğ–½ğ—subscriptğ—ğ–ºğ–½ğ—\mathsf{t_{adv}}, the global models between two training process become close. This observation also can justify the model closeness statement in Theorem 2.

7 Conclusion

This paper establishes the first framework (CRFL) on certifiably robust federated learning against backdoor attacks. CRFL employs model parameter clipping and perturbing during training, and uses model parameter smoothing during testing, to certify conditions under which a backdoored model will give consistent predictions with an oracle clean model. Our theoretical analysis characterizes the relation between certified robustness and federated learning parameters, which are empirically verified on three different datasets.

Appendix A Experimental Details

A.1 More Details on Experiment Setup for Training

We focus on multi-class logistic regression (one linear layer with softmax function and cross-entropy loss), which is a convex classification problem. We train the FL system following our CRFL framework with three datasets: Lending Club Loan Data (LOAN)Â (Kan, 2019), MNISTÂ (LeCun & Cortes, 2010), and EMNISTÂ (Cohen etÂ al., 2017). The financial dataset LOAN is a tabular dataset that contains the current loan status (Current, Late, Fully Paid, etc.) and latest payment information, which can be used for loan status prediction. It consists of 1,808,534 data samples and we divide them by 51 US states, each of whom represents a client in FL, hence the data distribution is non-i.i.d. 80% of data samples are used for training and the rest is for testing. EMNIST is an extended MNIST dataset that contains 10 digits and 37 letters. In the two image datasets, we split the training data for FL clients in an i.i.d. manner. The data description and other parameter setups are summarized in TableÂ 1. For these datasets, the local learning rate Î·isubscriptğœ‚ğ‘–\eta_{i} is 0.001 for all clients. The server performs an adaptive norm clipping threshold ÏtsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡\rho_{t} that increases by time so that the normal learning ability of the model can be preserved (described in TableÂ 1), and sets the fixed training noise level Ïƒt=0.01subscriptğœğ‘¡0.01\sigma_{t}=0.01 (t<Tğ‘¡ğ‘‡t<T). When the clipping threshold is not a fixed value, Lğ’µsubscriptğ¿ğ’µL_{\mathcal{Z}} is calculated based on Ïğ—ğ–ºğ–½ğ—subscriptğœŒsubscriptğ—ğ–ºğ–½ğ—\rho_{\mathsf{t_{adv}}} following LemmaÂ 1 for our experiment,.

Regarding the attack setting, by default, we set R=1ğ‘…1R=1, and if there are more adversarial clients, we use same parameters setups for all of them. For the pixel-pattern backdoor in MNIST and EMNIST, the attackers add the backdoor pattern (see Figure.Â 10 for an example) in images and swap the label of any sample with such patterns into the target label, which is â€œdigit 0â€. Similarly, for the preprocessed111We preprocess LOAN by dropping the features which are not digital and cannot be one-hot encoded, and then normalizing the rest 90 features and so that the value of each feature is between 0 and 1. LOAN dataset, the attackers increase the value of the two features (i.e., num_tl_120dpd_2m, num_tl_90g_dpd_24m) as a backdoor pattern, and swap label to â€œDoes not meet the credit policy. Status:Fully Paidâ€. Since we adopt LemmaÂ 1 for our experiments, we focus on the backdoor pattern â€–Î´iâ€–=â€–Î´ixâ€–normsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘–normsubscriptğ›¿subscriptğ‘–ğ‘¥\|\delta_{i}\|=\|\delta_{i_{x}}\|. The magnitude of backdoored pattern in every example is â€–Î´iâ€–=0.1normsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘–0.1\|\delta_{i}\|=0.1 on three datasets. Every attackerâ€™s batch is mixed with correctly labeled data and such backdoored data with poison ratio qBi/nBisubscriptğ‘subscriptğµğ‘–subscriptğ‘›subscriptğµğ‘–q_{B_{i}}/n_{B_{i}}.

We train the FL global model until convergence and then use our certification in AlgorithmÂ 2 for robustness evaluation.

B.2 Problem Definition

As described in Algorithm 1, due to the Gaussian noise perturbation mechanism, in each iteration the global model can be viewed as a random vector with the Gaussian smoothing measure Î¼ğœ‡\mu. We use the f-divergence between Î¼â€‹(â„³â€‹(Dâ€²))ğœ‡â„³superscriptğ·â€²\mu(\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime})) and Î¼â€‹(â„³â€‹(D))ğœ‡â„³ğ·\mu(\mathcal{M}(D)) as a statistical distance for measuring model closeness. According to the data post-processing inequality, when we interpret each round of CRFL as a probability transition kernel, i.e., a Markov Kernel, the contraction coefficient of Markov Kernel can help bound the divergence over multiple training rounds of FL.

After Model Replacement Attack

After ğ—ğ–ºğ–½ğ—subscriptğ—ğ–ºğ–½ğ—\mathsf{t_{adv}}, all clients use the original clean datasets to update their local model. Therefore, we use Markov Kernel to quantify the poisoning effect. When t>ğ—ğ–ºğ–½ğ—ğ‘¡subscriptğ—ğ–ºğ–½ğ—t\textgreater\mathsf{t_{adv}}, we have w~tâˆ’1â€²âˆ¼Î¼tâˆ’1â€²similar-tosubscriptsuperscript~ğ‘¤â€²ğ‘¡1subscriptsuperscriptğœ‡â€²ğ‘¡1\widetilde{w}^{\prime}_{t-1}\sim\mu^{\prime}_{t-1}, then Î¼tâ€²=âˆ«Î¼tâˆ’1â€²â€‹(dâ€‹y)â€‹Ktâ€‹(y).subscriptsuperscriptğœ‡â€²ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğœ‡â€²ğ‘¡1ğ‘‘ğ‘¦subscriptğ¾ğ‘¡ğ‘¦\mu^{\prime}_{t}=\int\mu^{\prime}_{t-1}(dy)K_{t}(y). Appendix C Proofs of Parameter Smoothing

In this section, we explain our parameter smoothing for general f-divergence, and give closed-form certification for KL divergence, which corresponds to the proofs for our TheoremsÂ 3.

We note that the function fâ€‹(â‹…)ğ‘“â‹…f(\cdot) used in f-divergence is convex. As shown in (Dvijotham etÂ al., 2020) (but for input smoothing), for perturbation sets ğ’Ÿw,Ïµ={Î¼â€‹(wâ€²):dâ€‹(w,wâ€²)â‰¤Ïµ}={Î½:Dfâ€‹(Î½âˆ¥Î¼â€‹(w))â‰¤Ïµ}subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¤italic-Ïµconditional-setğœ‡superscriptğ‘¤â€²ğ‘‘ğ‘¤superscriptğ‘¤â€²italic-Ïµconditional-setğœˆsubscriptğ·ğ‘“conditionalğœˆğœ‡ğ‘¤italic-Ïµ\mathcal{D}_{w,\epsilon}=\{\mu(w^{\prime}):d(w,w^{\prime})\leq\epsilon\}=\{\nu:D_{f}(\nu\|\mu(w))\leq\epsilon\} specified by a f-divergence Dfsubscriptğ·ğ‘“D_{f} bound Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, this certification task can be solved efficiently using convex optimization.

Remark.

The challenges are: 1) we divide both the LHS and RHS of Eq.Â 42 by 1z1ğ‘§\frac{1}{z} to obtain Eq.Â 43, otherwise the derivative of the LHS of Eq.Â 42 cannot be calculated directly. Finally, we restate our Theorem Â 3 here.

Proof.

We use LemmaÂ 12 to prove Theorem Â 3. In practice, since the server does not know the global model in the current FL system is poisoned or not, we assume the model is already backdoored and derive the condition when its prediction will be certifiably consistent with the prediction of the clean model.
